title: Zynex officials indicted for health care fraud - BioWorld
description: The U.S. Department of Justice reported that it has indicted two executives with Zynex Inc. for Medicare fraud, but in one of the stranger twists in recent fraud cases, one of the executives allegedly attempted to interfere with the personal lives of members of the media who were reporting on the company’s legal problems.

title: IDs and Tricare : r/MilitaryWives - Reddit
description:
You may want to mention which service he’s joining.
They all do it a bit differently.
For most, you’ll have the DD1172 form sent to you after they arrive as training and then you go to your nearest RAPIDS office to get your ID.
It is also possible to register yourself if you have a Power of Attorney and all the correct paperwork (usually Marriage certificate, social security card, drivers license, birth certificate or other additional ID).
Once you’re in DEERS, you can call Tricare to enroll in whichever version you prefer and is available in your area.
text:
You may want to mention which service he’s joining. They all do it a bit differently. For most, you’ll have the DD1172 form sent to you after they arrive as training and then you go to your nearest RAPIDS office to get your ID.

It is also possible to register yourself if you have a Power of Attorney and all the correct paperwork (usually Marriage certificate, social security card, drivers license, birth certificate or other additional ID).

Once you’re in DEERS, you can call Tricare to enroll in whichever version you prefer and is available in your area.

title: TriCare's $87.6M integrated expansion of coastal retirement village on exhibition
description:
The family-owned aged care and retirement village operator has been operating 91 independent living units across three buildings at the site which were approved in May 2007.
TriCare had originally sought to build 94 supported living units and 67 residential aged care beds across four buildings.
The application, environmental impact statement and accompanying documents are on exhibition from Tuesday 20 January 2026 until Monday 2 February 2026.
You can view these documents online here.
The population of Hastings Point, NSW, was 661 people in the 2021 Census.
text:
The family-owned aged care and retirement village operator has been operating 91 independent living units across three buildings at the site which were approved in May 2007.

Now TriCare wants to expand its site in Hastings Point, a town in NSW’s Tweed Shire, with a $87.6 million project for:

a four-storey residential care facility (Building D) with 47 beds;

three four-storey residential flat buildings (Buildings E-G) with a total of 51 independent living units;

ancillary facilities located within Building D including a café, communal lounge and dining areas, staff offices and nurse stations;

on-site communal facilities including a lawn bowls area and pavilion, an indoor swimming pool and a walking trail along the perimeter of the site; and

115 parking spaces.

TriCare had originally sought to build 94 supported living units and 67 residential aged care beds across four buildings.

The application, environmental impact statement and accompanying documents are on exhibition from Tuesday 20 January 2026 until Monday 2 February 2026.

You can view these documents online here.

The population of Hastings Point, NSW, was 661 people in the 2021 Census.

title: Trump says the DOJ is looking into Rep. Ilhan Omar for allegedly being worth $44 million
authors: CHARLOTTE HAZARD, The National News Desk
description:
President Donald Trump on Monday announced that the Department of Justice and Congress will be “looking into” Democratic Minnesota Congresswoman Ilhan Omar.
“Additionally, the DOJ and Congress are looking at “Congresswoman” Illhan Omar, who left Somalia with NOTHING, and is now reportedly worth more than 44 Million Dollars,” Trump wrote on TRUTH Social Monday morning.
In the same announcement, he also said that border czar Tom Homan would be going into Minnesota this evening.
“He has not been involved in that area, but knows and likes many of the people there.
Tom is tough but fair, and will report directly to me,” Trump’s TRUTH post reads.
text:
President Donald Trump on Monday announced that the Department of Justice and Congress will be “looking into” Democratic Minnesota Congresswoman Ilhan Omar.

“Additionally, the DOJ and Congress are looking at “Congresswoman” Illhan Omar, who left Somalia with NOTHING, and is now reportedly worth more than 44 Million Dollars,” Trump wrote on TRUTH Social Monday morning.

In the same announcement, he also said that border czar Tom Homan would be going into Minnesota this evening.

“He has not been involved in that area, but knows and likes many of the people there. Tom is tough but fair, and will report directly to me,” Trump’s TRUTH post reads.

Earlier this month, House Republicans launched an investigation into Omar’s finances.

The probe, first reported by the New York Post, is about how Omar’s household assets increased by a large amount during her time in office.

The Post said the lawyers are looking into on how Omar and her husband Tim Mynett "went from nearly broke to being worth up to $30 million in just a year," citing disclosure documents from 2024.

Last month, Omar denied reports that she was a millionaire.

"Since getting elected, there has been a coordinated right-wing disinformation campaign claiming all sorts of wild things, including the ridiculous claim I am worth millions of dollars which is categorically false," Omar said during an interview with Business Insider.

title: City of York reminds residents to clear snow, ice from sidewalks - CBS 21
description:
The City of York is reminding residents and property owners that snow and ice must be removed from sidewalks 12 hour after a winter storm ends.
"On sidewalks less than thirty-six inches in width, a path must be cleared that allows one pedestrian to pass at a time.
In a press release, the city said snow and ice removed from sidewalks cannot be put back into the road.
The city also said inspectors will patrol city streets for violations, which may result in fines.
“I’ve instructed City inspectors to give our residents a bit of grace today as people work to clear snow and ice.
text:
The City of York is reminding residents and property owners that snow and ice must be removed from sidewalks 12 hour after a winter storm ends.

Enforcement will begin Tuesday, according to the mayor.

"A sufficient amount of snow and ice must be removed to leave a cleared pathway at 36 inches in width for the entire length of the sidewalk in front of and abutting the property," the city wrote. "On sidewalks less than thirty-six inches in width, a path must be cleared that allows one pedestrian to pass at a time. Residents should keep a 3-foot radius around fire hydrants clear."

In a press release, the city said snow and ice removed from sidewalks cannot be put back into the road.

The city also said inspectors will patrol city streets for violations, which may result in fines.

“We understand that winter storms can make cleanup challenging,” Mayor Sandie Walker wrote in a statement. “I’ve instructed City inspectors to give our residents a bit of grace today as people work to clear snow and ice. However, enforcement of the Property Maintenance Code will begin tomorrow, Tuesday, January 27, 2026. We appreciate everyone’s cooperation in keeping sidewalks safe and accessible for all.”

title: TRICARE beneficiaries in Pennsylvania eligible for emergency prescription refills - CBS 21
description:
TRICARE beneficiaries in Pennsylvania are eligible to receive emergency prescription refills due to severe weather.
Refills are available through Feb. 5, according to a release from the Defense Health Agency.
The release says that beneficiaries should bring their prescription bottles to an eligible pharmacy to receive refills.
If possible, they should go to the pharmacy where it was originally filled.
Additionally, beneficiaries can call the clinician who prescribed their medication and have them order the refill to any pharmacy within the TRICARE network.
text:
TRICARE beneficiaries in Pennsylvania are eligible to receive emergency prescription refills due to severe weather.

Refills are available through Feb. 5, according to a release from the Defense Health Agency.

The release says that beneficiaries should bring their prescription bottles to an eligible pharmacy to receive refills. If possible, they should go to the pharmacy where it was originally filled.

Additionally, beneficiaries can call the clinician who prescribed their medication and have them order the refill to any pharmacy within the TRICARE network.

title: TRICARE authorizes temporary prescription refill waivers in Mississippi - WJTV
description:
JACKSON, Miss.
(WJTV) – The Defense Health Agency announced that TRICARE beneficiaries in Mississippi may receive emergency prescription refills now through February 2, 2026, due to the winter storm.
All counties are affected.
To receive an emergency refill of prescription medications, TRICARE beneficiaries should take their prescription bottle to any TRICARE retail network pharmacy.
If the bottle is unavailable or the label is damaged or missing, beneficiaries should contact Express Scripts, Inc., or their retail network pharmacy for assistance.
text:
JACKSON, Miss. (WJTV) – The Defense Health Agency announced that TRICARE beneficiaries in Mississippi may receive emergency prescription refills now through February 2, 2026, due to the winter storm. All counties are affected.

To receive an emergency refill of prescription medications, TRICARE beneficiaries should take their prescription bottle to any TRICARE retail network pharmacy. If the bottle is unavailable or the label is damaged or missing, beneficiaries should contact Express Scripts, Inc., or their retail network pharmacy for assistance.

outlet: DHA.mil - The Official Website of The Defense Health Agency
title: DHA launches Patient Advocate Assistance Reporting Tool to 'make sure that our patients ...
description:
The Defense Health Agency implemented a new system for patient advocates to track and manage patient feedback across the Military Health System.
The Patient Advocate Assistance Reporting Tool, or PAART, is the "new standardized, enterprise-wide system that will manage all patient feedback that is received by the patient advocates at all of our military medical treatment facilities," said Cmdr.
The system was developed to replace inconsistent legacy methods and give patient advocates a new platform to efficiently collect, track, and resolve patient concerns.
Capturing the patient experience PAART is a web-based secure portal designed to collect a wide range of patient interactions, including concerns, complaints, and compliments.
The tool will be used by all patient advocates at the unit, facility, and network levels.
text:
The Defense Health Agency implemented a new system for patient advocates to track and manage patient feedback across the Military Health System.

The Patient Advocate Assistance Reporting Tool, or PAART, is the "new standardized, enterprise-wide system that will manage all patient feedback that is received by the patient advocates at all of our military medical treatment facilities," said Cmdr. Gabrielle Crane, chief of the patient experience branch at DHA.

The primary goal of PAART is to use patient feedback provided to drive improvements within military hospitals and clinics, Crane said. The system was developed to replace inconsistent legacy methods and give patient advocates a new platform to efficiently collect, track, and resolve patient concerns.

"It's standardized and consistent," she explained. "The old process was fragmented within each MTF, and patient advocates had differing processes for how they managed feedback. The new system is exciting because now it will be streamlined and provide transparency enterprise-wide."

For military hospital and clinic leadership, PAART will provide data across the MHS and make better decisions to ensure data-driven improvements — ultimately enhancing the overall patient experience and safety.

At the core of the new platform are the patient advocates who help patients navigate the MHS.

“An advocate is the shipmate, the battle buddy, and the wingman," said Crane. “PAART enables an advocate to document interactions and ensure warm handoffs and transfers to the appropriate person who can provide service recovery."

Capturing the patient experience

PAART is a web-based secure portal designed to collect a wide range of patient interactions, including concerns, complaints, and compliments. Advocates can select preestablished fields including case date, type, location, and patient category.

The system categorizes cases by severity, which dictates the timeline for resolution:

Emergent cases, posing an immediate threat to life or safety, are flagged for immediate action.

Urgent cases, with a significant impact on health, have a 24-hour response time.

Routine cases are to be completed within 10 business days.

Crane noted PAART’s technology will flag cases to ensure meeting those windows, giving leaders "at each level an awareness of those timelines and where we are in meeting them."

The tool will be used by all patient advocates at the unit, facility, and network levels. Using the PAART system is mandatory for patient advocates — and a vital measure of effectiveness. PAART data can be used to analyze patient feedback and identify common trends, which ultimately assist in developing solutions as well as inform training programs for military hospital and clinic staff. The portal enables advocates to inform supervisors or military hospital and clinic leadership of concerns expressed by patients in their local area.

"It will allow us to see how we're doing across the entire system," Crane said. "We will be able to identify which areas we can work on or which areas we can leverage and are doing well. We can learn best practices and incorporate those best practices across our system."

Improving patient experience through PAART

Crane said the new system "allows transparency at all levels: at the MTF level, at the network level, and at headquarters.”

Through centralizing feedback, the DHA aims to foster a "culture of continuous improvement," Crane said. She noted the system strengthens trust by showing patients that the DHA created it with them in mind: When feedback goes into a system where it can be tracked, trended, and escalated, it counters the feeling that a complaint "goes nowhere."

"This was designed with the patient at the center of everything we're doing," she added, “we want to make sure that our patients’ voices are being heard and that they're being provided with the appropriate service recovery. That is what’s necessary to ensure the patient journey and experience is where it needs to be.”

Safeguards are in place to protect patient confidentiality. All users of PAART must complete Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act training, and patients can choose not to provide certain demographic information if they feel uncomfortable.

Looking ahead, Crane envisions technology will always evolve and that "we are here to ensure that our patient advocates at the MTFs have the tools, resources, and training that they need to successfully complete their job and be the advocate our beneficiaries deserve.”

title: #medicmonday | Military Health System - LinkedIn

For eligible beneficiaries questions or concerns, who receive their medical care from Branch Health Clinic Everett, please contact your Primary Care Medical Home Team via the patient portal or by phone at 425-304-4162.

title: Attention Soon-to-be Veterans: Understand TRICARE Transition Rules | Social Security Report
description:
His insights into the program’s funding mechanisms and his understanding of the demographics associated with the current and future participants in this critical senior program were the origin of Association’s position, resulting in the AMAC Social Security Guarantee.
The Social Security Guarantee (SSG) has undergone several iterations since its 2014 creation, each time adjusting the components to accommodate evolving conditions.
This process examined many proposed solutions presented in recent Trustees Reports and selected the alternatives felt to be best suited to save Social Security’s retirement trust fund.
A summary of the current AMAC Social Security Guarantee can be viewed on the AMAC.us website.
The Foundation’s projects and plans include providing factual information that improves understanding of the positive value of Social Security and Medicare and the current and long-term challenges these programs face, as well as providing interpretations by Certified Social Security Advisors through AMAC publications, workshops, webinars, podcasts, and telephone support.
text:
AMAC has been actively and aggressively focused on Social Security’s long-term future for the past decade, with Founder Dan Weber leading the charge for many years with his vision of how best to address the problem. His insights into the program’s funding mechanisms and his understanding of the demographics associated with the current and future participants in this critical senior program were the origin of Association’s position, resulting in the AMAC Social Security Guarantee.

The Social Security Guarantee (SSG) has undergone several iterations since its 2014 creation, each time adjusting the components to accommodate evolving conditions. Most recently, AMAC convened a dedicated working group to evaluate Social Security’s worsening financial trajectory and recommend changes to the SSG that would lead to its preservation and its modernization to meet the challenges of 21st Century economics. This process examined many proposed solutions presented in recent Trustees Reports and selected the alternatives felt to be best suited to save Social Security’s retirement trust fund. These proposals have been combined with our own research to achieve what we believe to be the best path to long-term trust fund solvency without the necessity of tax increases.

A summary of the current AMAC Social Security Guarantee can be viewed on the AMAC.us website. The full SSG research paper and recommendations can be downloaded from that site.

In 2013, AMAC—The Association of Mature American Citizens—took a big step with the creation of the AMAC Foundation, Inc., a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit entity designed to serve Americans. The Foundation’s mission is to help protect and ensure the financial security, health, and social lives of current and future mature Americans, and to help Americans navigate the bewildering array of decisions they need to make.

The Foundation’s projects and plans include providing factual information that improves understanding of the positive value of Social Security and Medicare and the current and long-term challenges these programs face, as well as providing interpretations by Certified Social Security Advisors through AMAC publications, workshops, webinars, podcasts, and telephone support.

In addition, the Foundation serves all Americans in a variety of capacities, including provision of a source of education on the principles of American Free Enterprise, long-term retirement financial planning, and preparing for life—and potential employment—after retirement.

We invite you to learn more about the Foundation and its operations at www.AmacFoundation.org

description:
Alaska Guard Helps Medical Evacuation in Midnight Operation The Alaska Army National Guard participated in a medical emergency evacuation on behalf of Kanakanak Hospital in Dillingham, Alaska, according to a DOD report.
Due to daylight restrictions on civilian aircraft, the Guard was the only group equipped to help transport the patient 50 miles south to the hospital who was ready to receive them.
DHA Introduces New System for Patient Feedback The Defense Health Agency (DHA) has begun to implement the Patient Advocate Assistance Reporting Tool, a new way to more efficiently collect feedback from patients, according to a DHA report.
The new system will replace former, disjointed legacy systems previously used to collect data, allowing decision-makers to have more accurate and comprehensive feedback information to drive the program forward.
National Guard photo by Nick Lime The appearance of U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) visual information does not imply or constitute DoD endorsement.
text:
Alaska Guard Helps Medical Evacuation in Midnight Operation

The Alaska Army National Guard participated in a medical emergency evacuation on behalf of Kanakanak Hospital in Dillingham, Alaska, according to a DOD report. Due to daylight restrictions on civilian aircraft, the Guard was the only group equipped to help transport the patient 50 miles south to the hospital who was ready to receive them.

DHA Introduces New System for Patient Feedback

The Defense Health Agency (DHA) has begun to implement the Patient Advocate Assistance Reporting Tool, a new way to more efficiently collect feedback from patients, according to a DHA report. The new system will replace former, disjointed legacy systems previously used to collect data, allowing decision-makers to have more accurate and comprehensive feedback information to drive the program forward.

National Guard photo by Nick Lime

The appearance of U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) visual information does not imply or constitute DoD endorsement.

title: How a New Report Could Transform Autism Care for Military Families - RamaOnHealthcare
description:
Healthcare Innovation Pietje Kobus Julie Kornack discusses the importance of the NASEM study, which exposes the misapplication of data leading to inadequate autism treatment coverage in the military In September, a congressionally mandated review from the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) concluded that the Department of Defense (DoD) is falling short for military families with autistic children, denying full insurance coverage for the gold-standard autism therapy and limiting children’s ability to receive that care in schools and at home.
The report recommends that TRICARE, the military’s health insurance, cover the gold-standard autism therapy, applied behavior analysis (ABA), as a basic coverage benefit.
Healthcare Innovation spoke with Julie Kornack, founding board member of The National Coalition for Access to Autism Services (NCAAS)... Today's Sponsor Related Articles:
text:
Healthcare Innovation

Pietje Kobus

Julie Kornack discusses the importance of the NASEM study, which exposes the misapplication of data leading to inadequate autism treatment coverage in the military

In September, a congressionally mandated review from the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) concluded that the Department of Defense (DoD) is falling short for military families with autistic children, denying full insurance coverage for the gold-standard autism therapy and limiting children’s ability to receive that care in schools and at home.

The report recommends that TRICARE, the military’s health insurance, cover the gold-standard autism therapy, applied behavior analysis (ABA), as a basic coverage benefit.

Healthcare Innovation spoke with Julie Kornack, founding board member of The National Coalition for Access to Autism Services (NCAAS)...

title: Guide to Tricare Substance Abuse Coverage | Avenues Recovery
description:
Tricare offers multi-tiered coverage for medical treatment for active military, veterans and their dependents.
In this article, Avenues Recovery shares guidance on eligibility and treatment options covered by Tricare, including Tricare substance abuse coverage.
Variations of these two main plans include: TRICARE Prime Remote TRICARE Prime Overseas TRICARE Prime Remote Overseas TRICARE Select Overseas TRICARE For Life TRICARE Reserve Select TRICARE Retired Reserve TRICARE Young Adult Call Avenues Recovery at 603-413-2877 to learn which plans work best for you.
Back to top Tricare Substance Abuse Coverage People receiving addiction treatment services from an approved provider such as Avenues Recovery can often receive Tricare substance abuse coverage.
Back to top Sources [1] nida.nih.gov [2] www.tricare.mil [3] www.tricare.mil [4] www.tricare.mil
text:
Substance abuse is a common issue among active soldiers and veterans. The stress and trauma that are part of military life can often cause personnel to turn to drugs or alcohol. Studies have shown that one in ten veterans are diagnosed with substance use disorder, a slightly higher proportion than the general population [1]. In an attempt to aid the recovery of military personnel and veterans, and help them and their families lead healthy, productive lives, the government established Tricare insurance. Tricare offers multi-tiered coverage for medical treatment for active military, veterans and their dependents. In this article, Avenues Recovery shares guidance on eligibility and treatment options covered by Tricare, including Tricare substance abuse coverage.

What Treatment Types Does Tricare Cover?

Included in the long list of Tricare-covered treatment are the following [2]:

Applied Behavior Analysis

Autism Spectrum Disorder

Cognitive Rehabilitation Therapy

Collateral Visits

Drug Testing

Eating Disorder Treatment

Electroconvulsive Therapy

Family Therapy

Gender Dysphoria

Intensive Outpatient Programs

Inpatient Hospital Services (emergency and non-emergency)

Management of Withdrawal Symptoms (Detoxification)

Medication Assisted Treatment

Office Based Opioid Treatment

Opioid Treatment Programs

Partial Hospitalization program

Psychoanalysis

Psychological Testing

Psychotherapy

Psychotropic Drugs

Residential Treatment Facility Care

Substance Use Disorder Treatment

Therapeutic Services

Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation

Conditions such as PTSD, depression, and all forms of addictions are covered by Tricare plans as well.

Locations for Tricare Insurance

Tricare is available across the globe [3]. Its management is split into three different regions.

Tricare West includes Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Iowa (excludes Rock Island arsenal area), Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri (except St. Louis area), Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oregon, South Dakota, Texas (southwestern corner including El Paso), Utah, Washington and Wyoming.

Tricare healthcare plans in this region are administered by Health Net. This means that Health Net serves as the contractor to the government to provide access and benefits to the end users, in this case active military personnel, veterans, and their dependents. They provide networks, claims processing, and education.

Tricare East includes, Alabama, Arkansas, Connecticut, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa (Rock Island area), Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri (St. Louis area), New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas (excluding El Paso area), Vermont, Virginia, West Virginia, and Wisconsin.

The contracting partner for the eastern region is Humana Military.

Anywhere outside the United States is called the overseas region, and is managed by International SOS.

Tricare Plans and Eligibility

Tricare offers several different plans, each with unique eligibility, benefits and costs. A common question we get asked is “does Tricare cover therapy for dependants of military personnel?”, and the answer is yes. Returned soldiers often have emotional scars that affect those they live with, in many cases to the extent that family members of veterans require therapy themselves.

Tricare Prime

Who can enroll?

Active military personnel and family members

Retired military veterans and dependents (until eligibility for Medicare is reached)

Those who have received the Medal of Honor and families

Activated members of the National Guard, and in some cases Reserve and Retired personnel.

Former spouses who fill specific qualifications.

Any member of Prime on active duty as well as their families have zero out-of pocket costs. All others are subject to nominal enrollment fees and co-pays.

Tricare Select

Select is accessible in the U.S. and is a fee-for-service program. All above-mentioned members are eligible, excluding those on active duty. Out-of-pockets costs will include annual deductibles and some cost sharing. This varies according to each client’s military status.

Select can be a great option for those who have supplemental insurance to Tricare, like Medicare or commercial insurance from their workplace, or people who are happy with their current healthcare situation and don’t want to change to an in-network Tricare provider.

In order to confirm your eligibility and registration, connect with a preferred Tricare addiction treatment center. Because Avenues Recovery is one of the Tricare-approved rehab facilities, we are authorized to provide Tricare benefits and can get you properly set up right away. Our staff will navigate the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System (DEERS) [4], get you registered, and connect with your Primary Care Physician (PCPM) to arrange necessary referrals. All you have to do is give us a call, and we will take care of the rest!

Variations of these two main plans include:

TRICARE Prime Remote

TRICARE Prime Overseas

TRICARE Prime Remote Overseas

TRICARE Select Overseas

TRICARE For Life

TRICARE Reserve Select

TRICARE Retired Reserve

TRICARE Young Adult

Call Avenues Recovery at 603-413-2877 to learn which plans work best for you.

Back to top

Tricare Substance Abuse Coverage

People receiving addiction treatment services from an approved provider such as Avenues Recovery can often receive Tricare substance abuse coverage. Medications and care for detox and residential treatment are all part of Tricare benefits. Furthermore, once a member is enrolled in Tricare-approved drug rehab programs like inpatient rehab and Partial Hospitalization Programs, drug and alcohol detox services may be included as well.

Does Tricare Cover Inpatient Rehab?

Yes! As long as you have been diagnosed with substance use disorder (SUD), are dealing with withdrawal symptoms requiring medical attention, and are having difficulties coping with daily routines, residential treatment is absolutely necessary and covered by your Tricare plans. This falls under emergency treatment.

In the event of non-emergency addiction treatment, such as when a person feels the need for treatment on his own, he must be authorized by Tricare or its managing partner. Avenues can help facilitate those authorizations upon contact from the client seeking addiction treatment.

Does Tricare Cover Outpatient Programs?

When qualifying, Tricare will give coverage for many types of outpatient treatments . Intensive Outpatient Programs (IOP) and PHP are often eligible. There are many individuals who while not needing round the clock medical care and supervision, greatly benefit from treatment groups and counseling sessions offered by Tricare preferred providers. The flexibility of such treatment gives clients the chance to resume their daily routines, family responsibility and jobs while remaining under the care of addiction treatment facilities. In some cases, Medication-assisted treatment (MAT) is necessary and covered as well.

Can Veterans Affairs Beneficiaries Access Tricare?

The Department of Veterans Affairs is a cabinet-level agency tasked with providing benefits and and support for military veterans in their time after service. The VA provides health care through its medical facilities and clinics across the country. Since 1995, every Veterans Affairs’ health care facility has been part of the Tricare network [5]. This means that they are able to service all Tricare members, including Active Duty personnel, retirees and their families on a space available basis. This is true for both primary and specialty care.

Tricare Addiction Treatment at Avenues Recovery

At Avenues Recovery, the gratitude we feel towards military personnel who have sacrificed greatly to protect us is endless. We will leave no stone unturned to place the chance for a normal, productive life within your reach without any financial hardship. So many mental health and addiction treatment options are available with your Tricare coverage. Our skilled staff will explain them all, facilitate the insurance coverage that is needed, and hold your hand through the entire drug and alcohol rehab process.

You deserve a second chance. Let us help you find the path to recovery! Contact us today to begin the process.

Back to top

Sources

[1] nida.nih.gov

[2] www.tricare.mil

[3] www.tricare.mil

[4] www.tricare.mil

text: 💪 Good Luck to our Best Medic Competitors from USARIEM! 💪 Two of our outstanding Soldiers from the US Army Research Institute of Environmental Medicine have been training and gearing up to compete in the grueling Army’s Best Medic Competition next week in San Antonio! The Best Medic Competition is a test of skill, endurance, and medical expertise designed to identify the Army’s top combat medics. This intense three-day event challenges participants with physically demanding tasks, tactical scenarios, and advanced medical procedures under pressure. It’s not just a competition—it’s a showcase of the critical skills that save lives on the battlefield. We are very proud to support our USARIEM Soldiers, SSG Tyler Nace and SSG Rigoberto Munoz, as they represent MRDC and demonstrate the strength, resilience, and expertise that define U.S. Army Medical Command (MEDCOM). Best of luck to all the competitors, but a special shout out to these 2 Soldiers—your MRDC family is behind you. You’ve got this! #BESTMEDICCOMPETITION #USARIEM

title: Defense Health Agency Civilian Corps Jobs - Marit
description:
The Defense Health Agency Civilian Corps is the civilian workforce component of the Defense Health Agency (DHA), the Department of Defense organization that manages the Military Health System and TRICARE administration.
Civilian Corps clinicians and healthcare professionals provide clinical, dental, behavioral health, and support services alongside uniformed medical personnel at military treatment facilities and DHA-managed markets worldwide, serving active duty service members, families, retirees, and other beneficiaries.
The Civilian Corps supports staffing across a broad range of clinical specialties, participates in military-civilian partnerships and research efforts, and recruits via DHA civilian careers portals (e.g., civilianmedicaljobs.com / civiliancareers.com).

The Civilian Corps supports staffing across a broad range of clinical specialties, participates in military-civilian partnerships and research efforts, and recruits via DHA civilian careers portals (e.g., civilianmedicaljobs.com / civiliancareers.com).

title: Looking for Resources on How to Explain TRICARE Benefits to my Fiancée. : r/army - Reddit
description:
Google tricare select costs.
Glasses are not covered by medical coverage but that’s standard for most civilian plans too.
She’ll also have to enroll in the tricare dental plan separately which is also a small fee a month.
You can Google tricare dental plan united Concordia to see a breakdown of their coverage.
Dependents enroll for optional vision and dental coverage (FEDVIP—same plans offered to all federal employees and federal/military retirees).
text:
Google whatever you’re looking for coverage for “tricare + whatever” and it is helpful. There’s 2 forms of tricare. Prime and select. She has to have select to for sure go off post and not need referrals. Some bases send civilians out off post with prime but not everyone so it’s not guaranteed. Google tricare select costs. You’ll find it’s substantially cheaper than most civilian plans. Glasses are not covered by medical coverage but that’s standard for most civilian plans too. She’ll need to enroll in vision insurance. It’s a small fee per month. She’ll also have to enroll in the tricare dental plan separately which is also a small fee a month. You can Google tricare dental plan united Concordia to see a breakdown of their coverage. There’s no premiums for active duty dependents and the deductible is Pennies compared to most of my friends civilian deductibles. Tricare covers most medically necessary things as long as there’s proper documentation.

You can enroll her in Tricare Select and she can go to any in network provider without a referral (some things still need prior authorization though). Active duty SMs/families have an annual $1,000 catastrophic cap, so you’ll never pay more than that for healthcare in a calendar year. My wife dropped her workplace coverage when we got married and did not regret it.

Dependents enroll for optional vision and dental coverage (FEDVIP—same plans offered to all federal employees and federal/military retirees).

You can find info on literally any question she has by googling Tricare + XYZ (like the other commenter said).

title: Rep. Rick Allen, colleagues seeking answers on Eisenhower Army Medical Center
description:
This week, Representatives Rick W. Allen (GA-12), Joe Wilson (SC-02), Austin Scott (GA-08), and Sheri Biggs (SC-03) sent a letter to the Honorable David J. Smith, M.D., Acting Director of the Defense Health Agency, seeking answers about potential changes in the scope of services provided at Eisenhower Army Medical Center (EAMC) at Fort Gordon.
Our offices have received multiple inquiries and reports of departments, staffing, and services at EAMC being severely reduced.
There is no equal military hospital within 300 miles, and our region experiences capacity issues and a lack of TRICARE-approved providers."
The members continue: "EAMC has consistently been ranked among the top military health institutions serving our Nation.
We look forward to a prompt response from the Defense Health Agency..."
text:
This week, Representatives Rick W. Allen (GA-12), Joe Wilson (SC-02), Austin Scott (GA-08), and Sheri Biggs (SC-03) sent a letter to the Honorable David J. Smith, M.D., Acting Director of the Defense Health Agency, seeking answers about potential changes in the scope of services provided at Eisenhower Army Medical Center (EAMC) at Fort Gordon.

In the letter, the members write: "As Members representing districts across Georgia and South Carolina, with over 20 military installations, our constituents and their dependents rely on consistent access to quality care. Our offices have received multiple inquiries and reports of departments, staffing, and services at EAMC being severely reduced. There is no equal military hospital within 300 miles, and our region experiences capacity issues and a lack of TRICARE-approved providers."

The members continue: "EAMC has consistently been ranked among the top military health institutions serving our Nation. President Trump has prioritized strengthening and rebuilding our military infrastructure and has directed a comprehensive approach to improving the quality of life and accessibility to services for those who wear the uniform. We fail to see how the effective closure of a respected facility serving an entire region furthers this goal."

The members conclude: "Pursuant to Section 714 in the FY26 National Defense Authorization Act, any changes in the scope of services must be preceded by assessments of impact and approval. We look forward to a prompt response from the Defense Health Agency..."

text:
Introduced

01/23/2026

In Committee

01/23/2026

Crossed Over

Passed

Dead

Introduced Session

2026 Regular Regular Session

Bill Summary

Virginia National Guard TRICARE Reimbursement Fund established. Establishes the Virginia National Guard TRICARE Reimbursement Fund for the purpose of reimbursing the costs of federal TRICARE dental insurance plan premiums and TRICARE Reserve Select health insurance plan premiums for Virginia National Guard members deemed eligible by the Adjutant General.

AI Summary

This bill establishes the Virginia National Guard TRICARE Reimbursement Fund, a special fund within the state treasury that will not revert to the general fund at the end of the fiscal year. This fund, administered by the Office of the Adjutant General and the Department of Military Affairs, will be used to reimburse eligible Virginia National Guard members for the costs of their TRICARE dental insurance plan premiums, as outlined in federal law 10 U.S.C. § 1076a, and their TRICARE Reserve Select health insurance plan premiums, as outlined in federal law 10 U.S.C. § 1076d. Eligibility for these reimbursements will be determined by the Adjutant General.

Committee Categories

Justice

Sponsors (1)

Last Action

Referred to Committee on General Laws and Technology (on 01/23/2026)
